content:
During World War II, the United States military did employ Native American code talkers to help secure communication by using their native languages to transmit coded messages that were difficult for the enemy to understand.

The use of Native American code talkers was highly effective in protecting communication and was used extensively by the U.S. military in both the Pacific and European theaters of the war. The code talkers used their native languages to communicate messages that were then translated by specially trained personnel on the receiving end, making it very difficult for the enemy to intercept and understand the messages.

The use of code talkers was so effective that the U.S. military continued to employ Native American code talkers in subsequent conflicts, including the Korean War and the Vietnam War.

Overall, the use of Native American code talkers was a highly effective method of securing communication during World War II and helped to contribute to the success of the U.S. military in several key battles and operations.
